topic.title: Implementing ZeroNet in other languages
topic.body:
ZeroNet currently seems to be mostly [written in Python](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/search?l=python), with a hint of [JavaScript](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/search?l=javascript). I've found that both on the clearnet and [this very forum](http://127.0.0.1:43110/Talk.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Topic:1_1EbkgVAJKgrTeYAmF3FSEJ8dRabpWH87it/When+the+f+k+can+we+get+rid+of+the+JS+s+t+so+that+we+can+really+use+0net+w+o+being+possibly+exploited+by+the+LEO), not everyone seems to like these choices of languages. I'm not suggesting the whole damn project *has* to move away from the two: there would be people to complain about the resulting version then.


So, If *you* were to re-implement ZeroNet, what would your language(s) of choice be, and why?


Personally, I would write all (or some) of it in [Erlang](https://www.erlang.org/) -- From what I know, It handles concurrency better than JS/Node.

Other languages mentioned will be listed here.

topic.title: What languages are permitted for automation?
topic.body:
I wanted to see an example of how to scrape the web with Zeronet, so I looked through the [optional files demo site](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1Gif7PqWTzVWDQ42Mo7np3zXmGAo3DXc7h). I found a file called updater.py, which seems to do the actual scraping.
This is odd, because I could have sworn that only Javascript/Coffeescript could interact with the [Zeroframe API](http://127.0.0.1:43110/Blog.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Post:46:ZeroNet+site+development+tutorial+2). Am I misreading something?

topic.title: Fonts and Themes
topic.body: Know of a pretty font or theme? Share it here!

topic.title: A mysterious site
topic.body: Apparently, [This](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1KPw7dMqE8Deij4nhLRCwbuwj9oFHysSHH) site is massively popular. I've seen it reported to have anywhere from 80 to 220 peers, probably more than any other site on zeronet. And yet... there's nothing there. Going through content.json (the only file to appear) answers some questions, though: there is meant to be an index.html file (245 bytes in size), and it has a hash. Also, the site was last modified Wed, 09 Sep 2015 18:03:46 GMT. The rest is signing data, which I can't learn much from. If anyone has a clue, please share.

topic.title: Regex for detecting Zeronet urls
topic.body:
Recently, a lot of people have been posting things on [0list](http://127.0.0.1:43110/186THqMWuptrZxq1rxzpguAivK3Bs6z84o) that are not zerosites. I figured a regular expression should do the trick, so I whipped one up:

The expression:
`/(http:\/\/)?(127\.0\.0\.1|localhost)(:43110\/.+)/g`

In JavaScript:
`text.match(/(http:\/\/)?(127\.0\.0\.1|localhost)(:43110\/.+)/g);`

Test it out [here](http://regexr.com/3cvbg).
Note that the actual url (1sitEuRl... or siteurl.bit) is not well verified in this version. I'm looking into fixing that.
**Edit 1**: This seems correct for detecting bitcoin addresses:
`[13][a-km-zA-HJ-NP-Z0-9]{25,34}`
Look [here](https://en.bitcoin.it/wiki/Address) for more detail.

**Edit 2**: The mostly-working second version:
`/(http:\/\/)?(127\.0\.0\.1|localhost)(:43110\/)([13][a-km-zA-HJ-NP-Z0-9]{25,34}|[^ \n]+\.bit)(\/?.*)/g`

topic.title: New encryption protocol we should switch to
topic.body:
Came across this recently, looks pretty secure.

Thoughts?

1_168qV1Xxp2EyszrzdECLUwXrn9wGYjDdar.body:
The guy who runs qntm.org publishes some pretty cool stuff. I may be able to convince him to mirror his site here. I may also be able reserve qntm.bit for him via Namecoin (possibly).

Side question: Is there any software for automatically mirroring a site on Zeronet?

3_1ED3Ho3kmzaKiECtyuqSjDpoE47rKuXeP.body:
I've installed zeronet on Ubuntu. It was slightly harder than on Windows, but still doable. Just follow the instructions on the webpage, (https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet) and you'll be fine. However, you may want to make an alias to start zeronet, otherwise you'll need to  point your terminal to the Zeronet-master folder to start. more info on that here: http://askubuntu.com/questions/17536/how-do-i-create-a-permanent-bash-alias

I have no experience with Mint, but I do like Ubuntu. Also, Arch is often considered more secure than either of those (although it has a far steeper learning curve). If you want to try Arch linux, I suggest starting with Manjaro.

Testing if simple html tags work. Nope.

3_1MmPY9fniJwwhP6WsgH4jWoq5rBAVV6KWy.body:
An installable iso for this would be nice. As for anonymous twitter, there is an existing version known as [Twister](http://twister.net.co/).
One question though: Why on earth would you choose Lubuntu? It's effectively barren compared to Xubuntu--which [seems to come with the Odroid anyway](http://www.hardkernel.com/main/main.php). Seems like an odd decision.
One other thing: this feels reminiscent of [Byzantium Linux](http://project-byzantium.org/). Shame it seems dead in the water.

> [kahpecuce](#comment_8_1MmPY9fniJwwhP6WsgH4jWoq5rBAVV6KWy): That would be the best solution for the social networking need in zerønet. But I think it requires the implementation of DHT in zerønet first, am I right?

Yep, DHT is a must. We rely on trackers right now, which are...well, centralized. But weirdly enough, [so little](http://zeronet.readthedocs.org/en/latest/help_zeronet/donate/) of the project donations have gone to DHT support.

> [kahpecuce](#comment_10_1MmPY9fniJwwhP6WsgH4jWoq5rBAVV6KWy): Which reminds me, I should chip in. :) doing it right now.

For DHT I take it?

> [kahpecuce](#comment_11_1MmPY9fniJwwhP6WsgH4jWoq5rBAVV6KWy): Yup, I just sent some to that DHT wallet.

Aaaaaand there it is! Yay for progress. Now if only I could remember where the hell _my_ wallet is. I have like $5 worth in there.

15_1PvAyLAB5H1JKbiFjx95ZJXrNJVyWxs5Hf.body:
> [vethit](#comment_1_1JdKZXpUz9vvevT99mmfTdbs3hjszJzqDX): Project Maelstrom - http://project-maelstrom.bittorrent.com/

They're very much like Zeronet--but closed source, browser-dependent, and without support for dynamic content. And yet despite being so shitty, they are the closest thing to a direct competitor on this whole list.

> [ekaterina](#comment_26_1Mk5sVKeCrwMc3wSD11jM7DZTiqF5D9BaD): >The blockchains are taking so long to sync and use up so much resources... It just doesn't scale.

[Here](http://iotatoken.com/) is one blockchain that is lightweight and may scale smoothly. It's not been released yet, but it looks promising. Not sure if it can store data like namecoin, but it *can* interface with Namecoin and Etherum. Give the whitepaper a read if it sounds interesting.

1_1KwTTgPRSTHFmmJAFBt6kQfdyNeSM5KJuH.body:
> [gomzik](#comment_48_1F6BMqittjWUStzUbRXm2kG2GQ3RdBLqFQ): But ofcourse you can rewrite python part in erlang. But, as I can see, python used with gevent, and it's make python more faster, when we talking about networking io

Seems reasonable. I know that Erlang doesn't really do exception handling at all (straight-up crashing is preferred)

> [gomzik](#comment_49_1F6BMqittjWUStzUbRXm2kG2GQ3RdBLqFQ): So, python is high level language, that helps make app more stable (you can't receive error, while working with memory directly or something like)
> I'm not understand, why people trying to use C\C++ to write applications for networks like that. Because security of these applications is very important thing

Supposedly so things can be as fast as possible. And if you write **very** carefully, you can preserve security.

> [gomzik](#comment_51_1F6BMqittjWUStzUbRXm2kG2GQ3RdBLqFQ): You can write in low level languages CPU bound tasks only, why not?
> Yeah, my english is not enough good, so I hope you understand me.

Given what I know of [Erlang](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Erlang_(programming_language)), It's at a high-enough level to handle managing processes well. That's part of the reason for my interest in it.

20_1ED3Ho3kmzaKiECtyuqSjDpoE47rKuXeP.body: I'm not sure how to do that, but [here](https://coderwall.com/p/lhsrcq/one-line-browser-notepad?p=1) is a neat, vaguely related way to have an editor using nothing but html. Example from the site [here](data:text/html;base64,)

> [zozon](#comment_105_1QBLGLcgKfcpfLmiDYuDzUKVXFfmTAew55): 
> Lot of fun. made my day. Thanks again pycole for bringing the subject to spotlight.

No problem. :) I came across that a few weeks ago and suddenly it's relevant (how cool is that?).
If you look thru the page It came from, I'm pretty sure there's another version that can *actually save* the created text file. A crazy enough person could integrate this with Zeroframe and make a WYSIWYG HTML editor--*almost entirely written in HTML.* The possibilities are crazy. It's so cool to see what HTML5 can do--even though it might not be finalized for years, and isn't even Turing complete.

> [oracle](#comment_131_1ED3Ho3kmzaKiECtyuqSjDpoE47rKuXeP): A wysiwyg editor would be great for ZeroNet for us non-coders, please try to create one if you can.

That's a challenge, but I certainly want to try. I also plan on making a GUI for creating new sites using [this tool](https://github.com/chriskiehl/Gooey). The only downside is that It probably won't be possible to embed it into Zeronet: running python from Zeronet [seems to be a no-no](http://127.0.0.1:43110/Talk.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Topic:2_1KwTTgPRSTHFmmJAFBt6kQfdyNeSM5KJuH). It may end up being a nice standalone app, though.

> [oracle](#comment_132_1ED3Ho3kmzaKiECtyuqSjDpoE47rKuXeP): Hope some of this helps you. 

Woah, that's a lot to work with. Since this looks like a fairly big task, don't expect it to be finished terribly soon--The last time I did anything super intensive with HTML was about two years ago. 
I'll try to have a rough version done by the 29th, but I have like five other neat ideas for sites that I want to try out too. If I don't have a draft by then, I'll post an update here.

Anything I *do* make will be posted on [Zerolist](http://127.0.0.1:43110/zerolist.bit). If I post something there, please seed it; I can't open port 15441 on my machine.

**Edit**: Shelved for now, It's a bit beyond my abilities. I will revisit this idea sometime in the future, however.

> [oracle](#comment_133_1ED3Ho3kmzaKiECtyuqSjDpoE47rKuXeP): Take your time and I'll make sure to seed it. Why can't you open your port? Who's your ISP provider? Modem?

The modem is my landlord's, and I don't have permission to mess with it.

> [oracle](#comment_135_1ED3Ho3kmzaKiECtyuqSjDpoE47rKuXeP): Sounds like you need your own modem.

Not really possible at the moment (personal life and stuff).

12_1PNyuY1iZqXBpft4ArouqcnE4pNRGYij5i.body: That rate's not going to stay constant. Chances are that as the project matures, there will be a spike in interest from less technically-minded users arriving. That's roughly what happened with the rise of the Internet itself, anyway.

2_1KwTTgPRSTHFmmJAFBt6kQfdyNeSM5KJuH.body:
> [nofish](#comment_349_1J3rJ8ecnwH2EPYa6MrgZttBNc61ACFiCj): 
> The updater.py is only for demonstration purposes, it has to run by site site owner.

Could it possibly be run another way--like on a timer, from a 'refresh' button on the page, or by being called by all.js? I'm already impressed by the level of automation here, and I would love to extend it further.

> [nofish](#comment_350_1J3rJ8ecnwH2EPYa6MrgZttBNc61ACFiCj): Sites can't run python scripts it would be unsecure, but if you make a copy of the GIF site and run update.py manually from console, then it's automatically download the latest gifs and add them to your new site.

I see. If I used a web scraper written in javascript (maybe like [this one](http://noodlejs.com/), or [this one](https://github.com/ruipgil/scraperjs)), could I set that to run automatically?

> [nofish](#comment_351_1J3rJ8ecnwH2EPYa6MrgZttBNc61ACFiCj): These scripts are also meant to be running from command line, they won't work from browser.

My bad, I didn't notice that. I'll keep looking for something that works in the browser (if it's possible).

3_1KwTTgPRSTHFmmJAFBt6kQfdyNeSM5KJuH.body:
Here are some of mine.

Fonts:
[Hack](http://sourcefoundry.org/hack/): A great font for code.
[Fantasque Sans](https://github.com/belluzj/fantasque-sans): Slighty whimsical, yet still good for code.
[Pontano Sans](https://www.google.com/fonts/specimen/Pontano+Sans): A nice curvy-ish typeface.

Themes/Colors:
[Monokai](https://atom.io/themes/monokai): It's been around for almost a decade, yet it still holds up.

Examples:
[Yeti's page](http://127.0.0.1:43110/195TNKe7aZbYT7cEjLXnKQ52487qpwas5x): Font seems to be called GlassTTYVT220. I'm not sure what the color scheme is, but It's nice!

> [testor](#comment_2_1Bs578fPj5LdtfwRBkvSRhDAFHDKx6wmoL): well, Hack font is very similar to Monospace :-|

Hack *is* a monospace font--that's just any font where all all characters are the same width.

1_16Sj4y8f1gVgm4kB8jcuh6HsW2MqJwGonF.body: For this to work, be sure you are using I2Psnark, not the standalone program known as Robert. If a link starts with maggot:// instead of magnet://, it's meant for Robert.

This is a good thing. More peers = more redundancy--even if it *does* mean more noobs asking questions that have already been answered.

7_17i7Y7r8nTaCfLbCAuaKyc4R5BbKZYU2Hr.body:
My app of choice: [PocketCasts](http://www.shiftyjelly.com/pocketcasts). It costs money, but it's hella worth it.
Oh boy, here we go. In absolutely no order:

[Welcome to Nightvale](http://welcometonightvale.com). If you don't know about nightvale, you're seriously missing out.

[Caustic Soda](http://causticsodapodcast.com). Three Canadian hosts talk about one caustic/dangerous/sensitive topic per episode. Not always safe for work. I recommend the episodes on mines, rabies, chemical warfare, and the entire series on the 5+ senses.

[No Such Thing as a Fish](http://qi.com/podcast). The staff of QI discuss various strange facts they've come across during the week. They get off topic plenty.

[Risk](http://risk-show.com). Highly NSFW. Features candid storytelling from many guests, some recurring. The three categories shows often fall into are sexy, adventurous, and tragic. The best are all three.

[RadioLab](http://radiolab.org). NPR show that dives deep into things you probably never thought about before.

[Damn Interesting](http://www.damninteresting.com). The title is a *massive* understatement. 

[The Truth](http://thetruthpodcast.com). Unique audio skits.

[Chilling Tales](http://chillingtalespodcast.com). These guys seriously don't fuck around.

If you end up liking any of these shows, consider tossing them a donation (most have a Patreon).
If I think of more, I'll add them.
You should put a master list in the description.

> [deafboy](#comment_15_1xf9XC4Nsa7YfQWFiK6xGsNDJA3AaCTUa): Same for me. I've removed it and tried to reinstall from f-droid, but last version wouldn't even download. Tried the previous one which worked fine. I sync all my subscriptions with gpodder for this reason.

Do any of those apps have an option for backing up your podcast list? If so, I'd suggest using it.

2_1HHSJHKhrpXzsGmtHhJmkk7hp2DZ9CRSN6.body:
As far as I know, you only seed sites you've downloaded--not all traffic, like other networks do (such as i2p).
To make a seedbox/helper node, I guess you would simply download as many sites as possible while not interacting with them much.

Edit: If you want to make a seedbox widely available, you could make a compressed zip file containing your data/ folder after downloading many sites.

9_1MEWJRMLgvofqG9Mbsb2Rc4hFFyv7HeRx7.body:
You can create a site without ever having a ZeroId, so that option is off the table.
However, you may be able to locate their IP address--unless they are protecting themself via the tor plugin.

The first place to look would be here:
http://localhost:43110/Stats

4_1MEWJRMLgvofqG9Mbsb2Rc4hFFyv7HeRx7.body:
> [angristan](#comment_56_1MEWJRMLgvofqG9Mbsb2Rc4hFFyv7HeRx7): Well, I'm seeding too :D

This reminds me of summer 2015. After _over two months_ of leaving Zeronet running 24/7, I was proud of myself for seeding over 2GB out. 
Damn--the network has really grown.

5_1KwTTgPRSTHFmmJAFBt6kQfdyNeSM5KJuH.body:
> [kaffie](#comment_60_1NWh3WAty57FH8at1WtrZigMrdhrDkuPzh): http://localhost:8080/1HeLLo4uzjaLetFx6NH3PMwFP3qbRbTf3D (different port)
Changing the ports requires a bit of reconfiguration, right? Anyone that's done so will know to change the port number when they try to visit the url.

Right now, I'm simply trying to write a regex that prevents a forum from accepting a non-zeronet url. I'm not dealing with proxies, custom port setups, or the chrome extension. The url forms my expression accepts right now are meant to be usable by as many people as possible--just click and go.

1_1E5qiz3ku3EzkMaUSj7mSSVJGtecNTGtBj.body: If you need it, the tutorial is [here](http://zeronet.readthedocs.org/en/latest/using_zeronet/create_new_site/).

No problem.You might also want to look [Here](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1NQSaE4rV83oeDVzDVryMNFSCqwz2gAaB4/?Post:4:EZTerminal:+Windows+Terminal+for+Creating,+Building,+and+Publishing+Sites) for a simplified version Mod has made.
And on someone's blog (can't remember who), there is a tutorial for vanity addresses. I'll see if I can find it.

1_1DfCtyHHrhkEYTyTAPhqQprTD1pHYMtrXz.body:
Visiting the link downloads a file called chrome_0.vbs, which both Chrome and my antivirus registered as a threat. I was able to download it by using an older browser and disabling my antivirus (don't ever do that, kids). The file starts with:
````
'HEX V1.1 "
BY>:KING OF MASS 
Copyright (C) 2015
````
And then has:
`off = off & php("44696D2054677568725277434270564555554254416A4176734570416C7A7165694E66674A45414458426E7070746C544966797065756F424C516758477565556E674F616D53506D4D6A7949756C5852")`

This line is repeated with 1,185 different strings of varying length, which I suspect are hashes.
The last two lines read:

`ExecuteGlobal off`
`Function php(off) : For y = 1 To Len(off) Step 2 : ub = ub & Chr(Clng("&H" & Mid(off, y, 2))) : Next : php = ub : End Function`

In short, I have no idea what this whole file does.

If you think you've done this by mistake, I heavily encourage you to run your antivirus program (back up users.json if you want to save your username, unless your antivirus found that file to be infected). Then, uninstall whatever you have at the moment. 
The actual downloads are here:
https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet#user-content-how-to-join

If you are deliberately trying to fuck up other people's devices, please stop. Being an asshole is a terrible way to make friends.

1_19LkvdTE3CmnUApuSwY8KGbm7n7sWCNEPC.body:
Registering a domain [costs .01 NMC](https://wiki.namecoin.info/index.php?title=Register_and_Configure_.bit_Domains#How_much_does_it_cost), and renewing one costs 0 NMC (which gives another ~6 months of ownership). Both are subject to a .005 transaction fee.

An entire Namecoin will last you... well, [a damn long time](http://goo.gl/LufXyC).
Even the mere 0.07 USD worth that I have is good for [nearly a decade](http://goo.gl/pldWBv).

6_1NWh3WAty57FH8at1WtrZigMrdhrDkuPzh.body:
For decentralized freedom from ICANN, [cjdns](https://github.com/cjdelisle/cjdns) is the way to go, but we don't have ipv6 support yet.
ZN does use trackers, as seen  [here](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/blob/master/src/Config.py#L33). 
[DHT](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_hash_table) is a much more decentralized method of peer negotiation, although possibly less secure in this context (according to an old conversation I had with nofish, can't remember where). 
If you have a sturdy understanding of Python and data structures, please feel free to [help out](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/issues/57). If you have bitcoin, you can provide some monentary motivation [here](http://zeronet.readthedocs.org/en/latest/help_zeronet/donate/#dht-support).

> [error404](#comment_4_1CWttfFnJgQmZifX8FbZn9dZ3xaTfooSJd): So right now, if the ZeroNet servers goes offline, the ZeroNet dies?

Not quite. Of all the [listed trackers](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/blob/master/src/Config.py#L33), nofish only owns boot.zeronet.io, and maybe (not sure) the onion one. The rest are big-time public trackers; all of them handle many thousands of requests a day. The chances that all of them might be down at the same time are ludicrous.

**Edit**: even if that *somehow* happened, there are [dozens](https://www.reddit.com/r/opentrackerproject/) more trackers available, and it's certainly possible to [run one yourself](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparison_of_BitTorrent_tracker_software).

> [error404](#comment_5_1CWttfFnJgQmZifX8FbZn9dZ3xaTfooSJd): does the ZeroNet uses the same trackers as the bittorrent network?

Again, the trackers are [here](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/blob/master/src/Config.py#L33). I'm not sure who owns the onion one, boot.zeronet.io seems to be Zeronet-exclusive, and the rest are common public trackers.

2_14TDWFVHuTXNcg8pp6LRr7v9ZcfbFsMSyx.body:

[Here](https://www.npmjs.com/package/namecointool) is a node package that seems able to query names and expiration dates, and [This](https://hackage.haskell.org/package/rosa) seems to be a Haskell tool for the same purpose.

3_1BidR2Pw65fTPeh1R3LbwCdfEJUPB6FLes.body: Definitely would be neat. On the same-ish topic, you might also want to look into [electron](http://electron.atom.io/).

4_1JHQA9oFkFpFFRiscyT4N71AKLWg46pQ92.body:
Full I2p support seems to be planned, but there are some kinks to work out first (see the [Github page](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/issues/45)). 
In the meantime, [BOB](https://geti2p.net/en/docs/api/bob) (the Basic open Bridge) may be of use: It lets non i2p-aware applications communicate over i2p. That's probably not ideal (and might be too demanding on i2p's network), but nobody seems to have the 'best' way to do this just yet.

> [cer](#comment_7_1JHQA9oFkFpFFRiscyT4N71AKLWg46pQ92): Do you have any idea (tutorial) to configure Zeronet with BOB for I2P?

There's something of a guide [here](https://geti2p.net/en/get-involved/develop/applications). Like it's been said on the github issue page (see my earlier comment), There are some issues that need to be resolved first. But after looking at the [options for possible APIs to use](https://geti2p.net/en/get-involved/develop/applications#options), I'm not sure what would suit ZN best. BOB? I2pTunnel? the full streaming library? I can't say just yet.
Here's how I suggest proceeding: fork ZN, get a friend or two to install your fork, mess around with different tools, gather some benchmarks, get feedback. That's a good way to start.

15_1CMYxdit4qq9QGk9DYRu2ruRPd2YDGckH8.body: With luck (and plenty of effort), we can prevent experiencing our own [Eternal September](http://knowyourmeme.com/memes/eternal-september).

Your personal site/blog is like your house: you can say _whatever the fuck you want_ in it. If you and some others want to have a good laugh about that one minority joke you love or whatever, that's fine. *You* own the site, and it's *your guests* that leave (and stop seeding) if they get fed up.
The general sites are like public parks: If you're being overly caustic, **you** may get shown the door. That's not censorship, [it's you being asked to be less of an ass](https://xkcd.com/1357/). The line between bluntness and decency is blurry, but being told to GTFO is a hint.

> [kaffie](#comment_96_1NWh3WAty57FH8at1WtrZigMrdhrDkuPzh): To add to this, there's a difference between presenting an opposing view (hitler was right, for instance) and talking about it in a decent humane way, and simply spamming shit and hating on people with no real room for discussion on a public forum.
> 
Right. And since the barrier to entry for making your own site is pretty low (basic html/css/javascript knowledge, or just knowing how to press the 'clone' button), it can hardly be called censorship. It's not being banned from a platform: a set of people are just refusing to be your audience.

...Which we're doing a decent job of right now, I'd say.

10_17i7Y7r8nTaCfLbCAuaKyc4R5BbKZYU2Hr.body:
> [a4io5ziuf436y0df](#comment_2_1AxJtqoxhNyjRjUptGgVoVHxgxtKRzUrpY): Do you trust Javascript to do the crypto for you? (I'm not bashing languages)
> Because that sounds like a pretty clever and rather unthought-of solution.

Javascript's crypto landscape [doesn't look too bad](https://www.npmjs.com/search?q=cryptography). Hell, we even have [EEC](https://www.npmjs.com/package/elliptic) and [AES](https://github.com/middleout/angular-cryptography) available. No idea if either's been audited though.
Edit: [Forge](https://github.com/digitalbazaar/forge) is also pretty competent looking

> [basxto](#comment_85_1PVcdu7USZH2kHMETbqDYLPjJZKCDWM52k): I wouldn't call ZeroNet as such, because it is even though it's probably not indexable (much JavaScript) pretty easy to use for average users. You can use ZeroNet use via a proxy without noteworthy cutbacks. You can also easily link it from clearnet sites. (which I already did)

You can browse tor via proxy too: here's the onion mirror of [Bluish Coder's site](https://mh7mkfvezts5j6yu.onion.to/) run by the onion.to service. And for even more weirdness, [here's](https://zerowrohotccypak.onion.to/1HeLLo4uzjaLetFx6NH3PMwFP3qbRbTf3D/) a proxy into tor that points to a proxy into zeronet (It doesn't seem to work, but it's still neat).

> [zarka](#comment_2_16R5J6zeFBmUQB2QM4ZgZMw8DxM4MnwcPr): Hey,If you assume deep web = overlay network, then Zeronet is a deep web (like Bittorrent, I2P, Tor, RetroShare, whatever).A darknet is a network where you don't connect to unknown peers.Freenet, Retroshare and some other can be used as darknets but Zeronet can't.
> I personally think that there is no deep web. Why a part of the web would be more deeper than an other? It is mostly a word for people who don't really understand what is the web and what are theses network.

If [private sites](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/issues/62) are added, Zeronet will be able to function as a darknet.

As for the terminology: 'darknet' refers to content that is not indexed by search engines. If a search engine is like a fishing trawler, then 'darknet' refers to resources too deep to reach (without special equipment).

> [angristan](#comment_78_1MEWJRMLgvofqG9Mbsb2Rc4hFFyv7HeRx7): This is deep web, not darknet

Since additional software (or a proxy) is required to view content, I'd classify ZN as a Darknet.
Sources:
https://danielmiessler.com/study/internet-deep-dark-web/
http://www.brightplanet.com/2014/03/clearing-confusion-deep-web-vs-dark-web/
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Darknet

> [zerobunker](#comment_112_168qV1Xxp2EyszrzdECLUwXrn9wGYjDdar): we are part of torrent network.

Sorta. We use public trackers, but [not the Bittorrent protocol](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/issues/57) (see 3rd comment down).

> [nic0las](#comment_1_185cUi41KQ1XWqcXDLyBiUkETqFcs8gQTb): I think ZeroNet is part of the deep WEB. But Bittorrent and RetroShare.Web =/= Internet.

[Confirmed.](http://www.webopedia.com/DidYouKnow/Internet/Web_vs_Internet.asp)

2_13BepSu3vkeSQB3ZWkCDg7Lu5w64tfpeTa.body:
Pretending to be another website (phishing) is possible on the normal internet too; there are [tools](https://www.httrack.com/) available for downloading sites. The best way to deal with the problem either way is by bookmarking urls.

On ZN, we have a *slight* advantage, though. If you've already visited a site, you can browse it easily. If a new 'fake' site is made and you are lead there by a link, It'll need to find peers and download. Hopefully, You'll be thinking 'wait a sec, I already downloaded this site!' and be suspicious.

1_18ZfPCaU1pYAeos3A7YhZVgtsmXqXeRRW7.body:
I have a few comments:
When the time for adding DHT comes, which implementation is being considered? I'd reccommend Kademlia, since it has a decent [Python implementation](https://github.com/bmuller/kademlia) , has served both [CJDNS](https://github.com/cjdelisle/cjdns) and the [Telehash project](https://github.com/telehash/telehash.org/blob/dd23237c1ac19b6347624b609ac22bc184016bb6/v2/dht.md) well, and is at least [fast enough](http://www.cs.columbia.edu/~jae/papers/bootstrap-paper-v3.2-icc11-camera.pdf) to outpace Chord (not sure about Pastry, Koorde, or others though).

In a little while, I'll post a few DNS suggestions.

For DNS, I can suggest a few options:
**NXT**
Pros: 
1. Custom currencies/ assets can be created.
2. NXT's *alias* system offers the same functionality as Namecoin, with the addition that aliases can be bought from/ sold to other accounts. CJDNS uses them for its .hype domain.
3. Can store up to 1000 bytes of arbitrary data (or 42kb for a short time) which can be used to [build services](https://www.cryptocoinsnews.com/nxt-decentralized-voting-system-twitter/).
4. Has a built in voting system, could be used for domain ownership disputes.
5. Blockchain is pruned at specific intervals, reduces bloat.
Cons:
1. Steeper learning curve than Namecoin.
2. Supports plugins, but they aren't sandboxed.
3. It's Written in [Java](http://www.reactiongifs.com/yuck/).

**IOTA**
Pros:
1. ***Doesn't use a blockchain***. Uses a DAG instead (see the [whitepaper](http://iotatoken.com/IOTA_Whitepaper.pdf).)
2. Can Interoperate with blockchain-based altcoins.
Cons:
1. Still early in development --client isn't ready yet (a [tangle explorer](https://www.tangle.ninja/explorer) is available though).

1_1ARmoCDkmZkYWAMCipxPqbUoT4akypoPoE.body:
Honestly, there is none. That *may* sound horrifying--but strangely enough, it's the exact opposite.

Imagine that there was one single, absolute purpose to your existence. What if you wanted to do something different? You wouldn't be able to. *That* would be horrifying.

The meaning of life is to find out what kind of meaning **you** want your life to have. True, some doors might be closed to you, but there are still multitudes of possibilities. Find something you like, and *do it*.

Even if you feel trapped, you can still pull off amazing things. Take a look at the story of [Deng Thiak Adut](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=buA3tsGnp2s) if you want proof (and Google his name for more about him). I get close to tears of joy nearly *every damn time* I see that video.

Point is, **stay alive.** If you don't know what you want to do with your life, *ask people for help.* You don't need to go through life alone.

Oh, and [if you need it](http://www.suicidepreventionlifeline.org/)...

If you still need help: [this](https://www.reddit.com/r/changemyview/comments/4hd6ou/cmv_everything_is_meaningless/) reddit post is from a guy with a similar view. The comments in it may change your perspective like it did his.

Please, stay with us.

8_1CMjV2r4EBpFt8VCcWWZKDysZXPcPExRNN.body:
That's a huge task and would be very difficult without the [merger site](/Blog.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Post:85:ZeroMe:+Status+report) feature; storing every video on a single site is untenable. If you wait about two weeks, it should be done by then.

In the meantime, check [this page](/1qJ3EM5rTa2wPTBvJuCFjdLXjrBCgBkR8) out. It seems to be a working webtorrent demo.

> [testingzeronet12](#comment_25_1CMjV2r4EBpFt8VCcWWZKDysZXPcPExRNN): Also can I ask what the merger feature would allow for a site with my requirements? I don't fully understand what it is.

The merger feature will allow for many small zites to be part of a larger one--sorta (hard to explain). It'll make creating a video-sharing site easier, because if just one zite was storing all the videos, it would be way too big.
One other thing: the merger feature will include a demo zite called 'ZeroMe', which will explain this better than I can.
